content: Former Singaporean civil servant **Moses Lee Kim Poo** [PJG](/wiki/Pingat_Jasa_Gemilang) [PPA(E)](/wiki/Pingat_Pentadbiran_Awam) [PBS](/wiki/Pingat_Bakti_Setia) (born 22 August 1951) is a former Singaporean engineer and [President's Scholar](/wiki/President%27s_Scholar), serving as permanent secretary for the [Ministry of Labour](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)) (1994–1998), the [Ministry of Community Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_Community_Development,_Youth_and_Sports) (1998–1999) and the [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)) (1999–2005). Lee served as a chairman of [POSB Bank](/wiki/POSB_Bank) (1994–1998), [Central Provident Fund](/wiki/Central_Provident_Fund) (2002–2005), [Sentosa Development Corporation](/wiki/Sentosa_Development_Corporation) (2013–2019), Tote Board (2013–2021) and [GuocoLand](/wiki/GuocoLand) (2013–2022). Lee also served as a director of [M1](/wiki/M1_(Singaporean_company)) from 2015 to 2019. ## Early life and education On 22 August 1951, Lee was born in Singapore, and he was the fifth child. He had four brothers and five sisters, and they lived on a farmland located in [Changi](/wiki/Changi). Lee's father worked as a foreman for the transport division in the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force), and his mother was a homemaker. Lee received his early education at Telok Paku Primary School, and later St. Stephen's School. Upon completing his [Primary School Leaving Examination](/wiki/Primary_School_Leaving_Examination), Lee enrolled in [St. Patrick's School](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_School,_Singapore), and obtained a [Higher School Certificate](/wiki/Higher_School_Certificate_(England_and_Wales)). After graduation, Lee applied to [Malaysia–Singapore Airlines](/wiki/Malaysia%E2%80%93Singapore_Airlines) as a cadet pilot, but he was unsuccessful. In 1970, Lee was chosen by the [Public Service Commission](/wiki/Public_Service_Commission_(Singapore)) as one of eight [President's Scholars](/wiki/President%27s_Scholar).[a] In line with the Government's aim of training more engineers, Lee enrolled in the [University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore#University_of_Singapore_(1962–1980)). However, due to an overwhelming intake, Lee had to spend most of his time at the Prince Edward campus, instead of the main Bukit Timah campus. As such, lessons and practicals were conducted using facilities at the adjacent [Singapore Polytechnic](/wiki/Singapore_Polytechnic) campus. In 1974, Lee graduated with first class honours, and obtained a [Bachelor of Engineering](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Engineering) in [mechanical](/wiki/Mechanical_engineering) and [production engineering](/wiki/Manufacturing_engineering). In 1982, Lee graduated from [Harvard Business School](/wiki/Harvard_Business_School) with a [Master of Public Administration](/wiki/Master_of_Public_Administration). ## Career Although trained as an engineer, Lee was posted to the administrative service in 1974, serving in the development division of the [Ministry of Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Singapore)) (MOF). His first task was to write a paper about industrial land use. Two years later, Lee was transferred to the [Ministry of National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)). As the government was phasing out pig farms on mainland, Lee was tasked to study the feasibility of shifting the pig farms to [Pulau Ubin](/wiki/Pulau_Ubin). However, he concluded that there would be a logistical constraint of bringing supplies to and fro the island, and the idea was not feasible. Thereafter, under the chairmanship of [Cheng Tong Fatt](/wiki/Cheng_Tong_Fatt), Lee was part of a committee to transform Singapore into a "garden city", serving as its secretary. After graduating from Harvard in 1982, Lee was posted to the [Ministry of Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment). During this period, Lee was involved in writing progress reports and papers about the clean up of the [Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) and the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin) to the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore). Three years later, in 1986, he was transferred to the [Ministry of Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)), serving as director of personnel and planning matters. Lee oversaw the deployment of principals and senior management across schools. In 1987, Lee was appointed as [principal private secretary](/wiki/Private_secretary) to Prime Minister [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew). Lee accompanied PM Lee on all overseas trips, and assisted with drafting speeches and presentations. In 1991, he was seconded to the [Singapore Broadcasting Corporation](/wiki/Mediacorp) as its general manager, replacing [Wong-Lee Siok Tin](/wiki/Wong-Lee_Siok_Tin). In 1994, Lee was appointed as permanent secretary for the [Ministry of Labour](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)) and chairman of [POSB Bank](/wiki/POSB_Bank). In December 1997, Lee succeeded Er Kwong Wah as permanent secretary for the [Ministry of Community Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_Community_Development,_Youth_and_Sports). On 1 June 1999, Lee took over [Koh Yong Guan](/wiki/Koh_Yong_Guan) as permanent secretary for the [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)). ### Later years In 2005, Lee stepped down as permanent secretary, and he was appointed as commissioner of the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore](/wiki/Inland_Revenue_Authority_of_Singapore). He held the role until his retirement on 1 November 2012, relinquishing the position to Tan Kim Siew. On 1 January 2013, Lee became chairman of the [Sentosa Development Corporation](/wiki/Sentosa_Development_Corporation) and Tote Board, succeeding Loo Choon Yong and [Bobby Chin Yoke Choong](/wiki/Bobby_Chin_Yoke_Choong) respectively. On 1 November 2013, Lee was also appointed chairman of [GuocoLand](/wiki/GuocoLand). ## Personal life Lee is a [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church). While studying at Harvard, Lee and his wife had their first child. His wife is two years younger, and works as a lawyer. In total, they have four children. ## Awards and decorations - [Meritorious Service Medal](/wiki/Pingat_Jasa_Gemilang), in 2023. - [Long Service Medal](/wiki/Pingat_Bakti_Setia), in 1999. - [Public Administration Medal](/wiki/Pingat_Pentadbiran_Awam) (Gold), in 1996. ## Notes
